All continuous variables are winsorized at the 1st and 99th percentile. \*\*\*, \*\*, \* denote significance (two-tailed) at the $1\%$ $5\%$ ,and $10\%$ levels, respectively. T statistics (in parentheses) are based on robust standard errors clustered at the firm level.  

Taken together, these results shed light on the fact that enterprise digitalization successfully improves labor investment efficiency and firm value conditional on matched or complementary relationships between human capabilities and digital technologies.  

## 6. Cross-sectional tests  

To map associations between enterprise digitalization and labor upgrading across multifaceted aspects, we perform cross-sectional tests to examine some heterogeneous effects.  

### 6.1. Labor adjustment cost  

First, we examine whether or not our main effect is strengthened in firms with greater labor adjustment costs. We use two variables to proxy the variation in adjustment costs: SOEs and labor-intensive firms. The employment decisions of SOEs are strongly affected by policy burden (Lin and Tan, 1999; Gu et al., 2020). Therefore, it is difficult for enterprises to lay off or recruit a large number of employees (e.g., quasi-official, limited positions) in a short time. SOE is an indicator variable that equals 1 for firms controlled the by government and O otherwise. The impact of digitalization on labor upgrading may be more salient for labor-intensive firms due to their abundant workforce that can quickly be upgraded during digitalization. However, a surplus in the workforce may suppress labor upgrading in labor-intensive enterprises because humans in labor-intensive firms have a comparative advantage over robots (Acemoglu and Restrepo, 2019). Therefore, it is important to empirically investigate how digitalization affects labor upgrading in laborintensive enterprises. Labor intensity $(L I)$ is the number of employees divided by total assets for firm i in year t.  

Panel A of Table 9 reports the regression results based on the labor adjustment cost perspective. As expected, the coefficients on $L N D T{\times}S O E$ are significantly negative in columns (1) and (2) when the dependent variables are LNTECH and LNBACH, respectively. The coefficient is insignificantly negative in column (3) when the dependent variable is LNPROD. These results indicate that SOEs are even less likely to hire highly skilled and highly educated employees due to a lack of employee flexibility caused by policy burden. Policy burden also insignificantly reduces the number of production workers (Lin and Tan, 1999; Gu et al., 2020). However, the coefficienton $L N D T{\times}L I$ is significantly positive in columns (4) and (5) when the dependent variables are LNTECH and LNBACH, respectively. The coefficient is insignificantly positive in column (6) when the dependent variable is LNPROD. These results suggest that digitalization promotes labor-intensive enterprises to hire more highly technical and educated workers relative to non-laborintensive enterprises. However, this effect is not seen when the dependent variable is LNPROD.  

### 6.2. High technology  

The pace of digital transformation of enterprises may be affected by the level of a firm's technical talent reserves and acquired resources (Wu et al., 2022). High-tech enterprises possess more technical talent reserves and acquired resources relative to non-hightech enterprises. We further examine whether the effect of digitalization on labor upgrading is more pronounced in high-tech enterprises relative to non-high-tech enterprises. HIGHTEC is a dummy variable that equals 1 for firms categorized as high-tech by the government and O otherwise. We further include the interaction term LNDT $^{\bullet}\times$ HIGHTEC in the regression model.  

The results are reported in Panel B of Table 9. The coefficient on LNDT $\cdot_{\times}$ HIGHTEC is significantly positive in columns (1) and (2) when the dependent variables are LNTECH and LNBACH, respectively. The coefficient is significantly negative in column (3) when the dependent variable is LNPROD. These results reveal that enterprise digitalization has a more pronounced impact on labor upgrading in high-tech enterprises than in non-high-tech enterprises. Thus, high-tech enterprises have a strong incentive to adopt digital transformation and quickly update their labor force.  

### 6.3. The effect of different regions  

Finally, to investigate whether the digitalization of firms headquartered in different regions of China has different effects on labor upgrading, we construct a regression model according to whether an enterprise is headquartered in the eastern region of China (Wu et al., 2022). We define EAST as an indicator that equals 1 for firms that are headquartered in the eastern region and 0 otherwise (i.e., headquartered in the central or western regions).  

The results are reported in Panel C of Table 9. In contrast to the central and western areas, the coefficients on $L N D T\times E A S T$ in columns (1) and (2) are positive and pronounced in the eastern region when the dependent variables are LNTECH and LNBACH, respectively. The coefficient is insignificantly negative in column (3) when the dependent variable is LNPROD. This reveals that enterprise digital transformation has a greater impact on labor upgrading in the eastern region than in the central and western areas. This may be because firms in the eastern region have relatively advanced digital technology and a richer workforce that digital firms urgentlyneed.  

## 7. Conclusions  

Prior literature mainly focuses on how the rise of digitalization technologies or RPA affects the labor market. In addition, extant studies often focus more attention on developed regions and countries such as Europe and the United States (Acemoglu and Restrepo, 2020). Thus, there is a relative lack of direct evidence from developing countries. China, as the world's second-largest economy, is a typical representative of developing countries. A small number of studies have looked at robotics and artificial intelligence development in China and its economic impact (Cheng and Qu, 2020; Wu et al., 2022); however, they mainly focus on theoretical discussions and lack systematic empirical analyses. In this study, we fill this research gap by investigating how enterprise digitalization affects labor upgrading.  

We find that firms that have undergone a digital transformation have a greater demand for highly skilled and highly educated workers and a decreased demand for production workers. This indicates labor upgrading. We also find that digitalization helps firms to create an external labor demand for more skilled and highly educated labor, and promotes the additional training of existing employees. Further analyses show that digital transformation can improve labor investment efficiency and firm value (both book value and market value) of an enterprise only if the firm upgrades its labor force. Our study highlights the fact that the ability of firms to exploit digitalization successfully depends on a variety of complementary human capital and employee capabilities. In other words, the success of enterprise digitalization depends not only on digital assets but also on acquiring related human capabilities in the areas of digital technologies, digital networking, and big data analytics.

# Does a change in the information environment affect labor adjustment costs?  

Ben R. Marshalla, Justin Hung Nguyenb, Nhut H. Nguyen , Nuttawat Visaltanachoti a,\*  

Massey BusinessSchoo,Massy University,ewZealand b Victoria Universiy of Welington, New Zealand Auckland University of Technology, New Zealand  

# ARTICLEINFO  

# ABSTRACT  

Keywords: Information environment Information asymmetry Labor adjustment costs  

We consider how a firm's information environment impacts an index of three proxies for the costs it incurs when adjusting its workforce. We show firms with less information asymmetry have lower labor adjustment costs (LACs). Moreover, this relation is stronger for firms with lower financing constraints and stronger financial performance and growth, which suggests these attributes are particularly appealing to employees. Our difference-in-difference tests based on two exogenous asymmetric information shocks around broker mergers and closures, and decimalization indicate the link is likely causal. Finally, we show that LACs are an important channel through which information asymmetry impacts firm value.  

## 1. Introduction  

We consider whether a change in the information environment affects an index of three established proxies for labor adjustment costs (hereafter LACs). These costs, which include costs associated with adding and removing employees are a substantial expense for firms. Ghaly, Dang, and Stathopoulos (2017) note that LACs can equate to the oneyear payroll costs for the average worker. They are also an important economy-wide cost, which is reinforced by the Donangelo, Gourio, Kehrig, and Palacios (2019) observation that labor costs account for morethan $50\%$ of GDP, and the fact that many advanced economies have shifted employment toward labor-intensive service industries in recent decades (e.g., Whited, 2019). However, the various components of LACs are difficult to measure (e.g., Golden, Mashruwala, & Pevzner, 2020) so proxies are used. We, therefore, adopt three LAC proxies from the literature and combine them to form a LAC Index.  

A firm's information environment affects many aspects of corporate policies and there is reason to expect it to be a determinant of LACs. Hall and Lazaer (1984) note that information asymmetry is an important aspect of labor-firm relations given workers are not aware of all firmrelated information.? Firms operating in a poorer information environment are likely to find it more costly to attract new staff due to worker concerns about involuntary unemployment risk and its impact on their future earnings (e.g., Couch & Placzek, 201o). Hence, it seems most plausible that a reduction in information asymmetry reduces LACs. On the other hand, it is also possible that an improved information environment could increase LACs. For instance, if a reduction in opaqueness reveals information that is negative for employees (e.g., cash-flow shortage, competitive weakness, or poor workplace safety), firms may lose workers and find it more costly to attract new workers. This is consistent with the Ji and Tan (2016) finding that firms strategically modify their disclosure policies due to labor unemployment concerns. They are more likely to provide bad news forecasts when workers are likely to be less concerned about unemployment, especially when firms are financially constrained.  

We acknowledge that LACs are a broad concept relating to different stages in hiring, training, retaining, firing, and replacing an employee, which are difficult to quantify. Hence, we suggest that it is difficult to comprehensively capture LACs by a single metric. We, therefore, create a LAC Index based on three LAC proxies from the current literature. The first input (\*"Tightness Cost') is based on the return sensitivity to the labor market conditions. Kuehn, Simutin, and Wang (2017) show that firms with higher loadings on changes in the labor market tightness variable face higher LACs. The second component ("Skills Cost") follows Ghaly et al. (2017) and Golden et al. (2020) and relates to how highly skilled a firm's workers are. As the replacing process is more difficult for highly skilled positions, it is more costly for firms to fire skilled workers because of the likelihood of loss of firm-specific capital. The final factor ("Hiring Cost") is based on the hiring rate of new workers as Varejao and Portugal (2007, p. 162) note that “adjustment costs do influence the frequency of adjustment” with adjustment more likely in workforces with more temporary workers and low-tenure workers (where LACs are lower). We calculate the LAC Index using an approach that is similar to the method Lang, Lins, and Maffett (2012) use to construct their transparency index. We first rank firms based on Tightness Cost, Skills Cost, and Hiring Cost into percentile ranks yearly and then take the average of these across the three rank variables to construct the LAC Index.  

We follow Maskara and Mullineaux (2011) and form an index based on information asymmetry proxies that capture different aspects of a firm's information environment. The components of the information asymmetry index comprise of the market- and accounting-based proxies including (1) a measure of the responsiveness of stock prices to earnings changes, (2) the number of analysts following a firm, (3) the forecast dispersion of analyst estimates,(4) firm size,(5） the readability of financial statements, (6) a price delay measure, (7) serial correlation in stock returns, (8) the Llorente, Michaely, Saar, and Wang (2002) measure of information asymmetry, and (9) the bid-ask spread. We follow the Lang et al. (2012) index computation approach to calculate our information quality index (Info_Qual Index) by ranking firms for each of the nine variables into percentile ranks on a yearly basis and then taking the average of these across the nine variables.3 The percentile rank approach has two benefits. First, the three labor adjustment cost measures have a different unit of measurement so the aggregation using their raw values would introduce the biased index with higher weighting toward measures with a high unit of measurement. The percentile rank approach solves this issue and can create an unbiased index of the three measures. Second, the percentile rank approach reduces the impact of outliers on the analysis.  

While our LAC Index is based on established LAC measures from the literature, we acknowledge that it is not a definitive measure of the true LACs faced by firms. Therefore regardless of whether we refer to our results on the LAC Index or, for brevity, just LACs we are referring to the LAC Index measure we use in this paper. We leave it to the reader to decide whether the results are generalizable to other aspects of LACs. To that end, our results indicate there is a negative and statistically significant relation between information quality and the LAC Index. Firms with better information quality have lower LACs even after controlling for a comprehensive list of firm characteristics that may be correlated with both of the variables of interest, including size, profitability, leverage, liquidity (i.e., cash holdings), tangibility, growth potential (i. e., research and development expenditure), and labor intensity. Moreover, the effect is not sensitive to the inclusion of year and industry/firm fixed effects to account for macro-economic conditions and timeinvariant industry/firm factors which possibly drive LACs. In a robustness check, we use the inverse bid-ask spread as a proxy for information quality with larger sample size and find consistent evidence.  

Our result holds in general but is stronger when the increased information quality occurs in firms with lower financing constraints and better financial performance and growth prospects. This suggests that employees view companies with these attributes as more appealing workplaces. It is likely that employees perceiving these firms to have a high chance of success, and hence have a lower risk of having to fire staff or more ability to pay higher wages. We also show that LACs are a channel through which information asymmetry impacts firm value. In particular, increases in information quality improve firm value but this effect is more (less) pronounced if LACs are low (high).  

Our findings thus far, despite being robust, can at best only reveal a negative correlation (not causation) between the quality of a firm's information environment and its LACs. To better establish causality we examine two exogenous shocks to information asymmetry in a difference-in-difference setting. First, we use the natural experiment of Kelly and Ljungqvist (2012) involving broker closures. Analysts reduce information asymmetry by collecting and disseminating information from private and public sources (e.g. Brennan & Subrahmanyam, 1995; Lang, Lins, & Miller, 2003, 2004). We also use broker mergers, which are first used by Hong and Kacperczyk (2010). As Chen and Lin (2017) note, broker mergers are typically followed by a reduction in broker number due to analysts being fired. Second, we treat the move to decimalization in 2001 as an exogenous information asymmetry shock. Decimalization improves liquidity (e.g., Fang, Noe, & Tice, 2009) and liquidity increases encourage larger shareholdings and block formation (e.g., Edmans, 2009), which in turn, leads to greater management disclosure and less information asymmetry (e.g., Boone & White, 2015). Edmans and Manso (2011) show that liquidity makes blockholders more effective monitors through disciplinary trading, which results in the more managerial effort. The threat of blockholder exit is an important consideration for management (e.g., Bharath, Jayaraman, & Nagar, 2013; Edmans,Fang, & Zur, 2013).  

The difference-in-difference (DiD) results show that an increase in asymmetric information following broker closures and mergers causes an increase in LACs of treated firms relative to their control firm counterparts. The treated (control) firms are those that are (not) impacted by broker closures and mergers. Likewise, the decimalization-induced decline in asymmetric information results in a reduction in the LACs of treated firms relative to control firms. The treated (control) firms are those that experience the most (least) improvements in liquidity and reductions in information asymmetry following the decimalization. Note that in both DiD analyses we use the propensity score matching (PSM) technique to ensure treated and control firms have similar control characteristics immediately before entering an experiment. We, therefore, are more confident the observed relative changes in treated firms' LACs are most likely due to their changes in information quality around thetreatment shock.  

We contribute to two strands of the literature. The first is literature regarding the impacts of the information environment on firms. Billett, Garfinkel, and Yu (2017) find weaker industry-adjusted sales growth follows an increase in information asymmetry. Chen and Lin (2017) find increases in information asymmetry results in more aggressive tax avoidance, while Li, Li, Lin, and Zhan (2019) find an increase in information asymmetry causes firms to shift from equity and public debt financing to bank debt. Kim, Lu, and Yu (2018) show that increased information asymmetry increases firm expected crash risk. Our study extends the understanding in this area by showing a significant influence of information quality on a firm's relationship with one of its most important stakeholders, i.e., employees. In particular, we argue and provide evidence that an improved information environment facilitates the hiring, retaining, and hiring process, which leads to lower LACs in general. Given the heavy burdens of LACs on a firm's resources, such a reduction in this kind of cost is warmly welcomed by shareholders in the form of higher firm value.  

The second is literature on the link between corporate finance and labor market outcomes. Michaels, Page, and Whited (2019) find that increased financing costs lead to a reduction in employment and wages. Benmelech, Frydman, and Papanikolaou (2019) document that difficulties in accessing credit caused a large proportion of the decline in employment during the Great Depression. Caggese, Cunat, and Metzger (2019) suggest that financing constraints distort the trade-off between firing and hiring costs and worker productivity, resulting in firms choosing tofire workers with a short tenure even if they have high future expected productivity. Prabowo, Hoogiemstra, and Veen-dirks (2018) find that managers of state-owned enterprises can be influenced by the state when making decisions about laying off employees when sales decline. We add to this emerging literature by documenting a crucial role of a firm's information quality which enhances its success in adjusting labor forces. The effect is even more pronounced if the increased transparency reveals financially favorable news that is of the employee interests, such as high financial strength and growth opportunities. Our identification of information asymmetry based on two plausibly exogenous shocks (around decimalization, and broker mergers and closures)boosts our confidence that the link between information environment and LACs is likely causal.

Section 3 contains a description of the data, variables, and descriptive statistics. The results are presented in Section 4, while Section 5 concludes the paper.  

## 2. Related literature  

### 2.1. Labor adjustment costs  

There are different dimensions to LACs with no single measure capturing all aspects of the costs incurred by firms when there are personnel changes. The LAC literature, which dates back to Oi (1962) has, to date, used many LAC proxies. Cross-country studies typically use variation in employment protection legislation (EPL) provisions as these are a useful source of variation in the firing cost dimension of LACs. For instance, Banker, Byzalov, and Chen (2013) find that cost stickiness at the firm level varies with the strictness of EPL provisions at the country level. Within country LAC studies have, in recent times, typically used one of three LAC proxies. In this paper, we create an index based on all three measures. Kuehn et al. (2017) suggest that the impact of changes in the tightness of the labor market on a firm's stock returns is an indication of that company's LACs. When the labor market tightens and the number of job vacancies to the number of unemployed workers decreases, all firms find it more difficult to attract new staff. However, some firms find it more difficult than others. It is these firms that have higher LACs relative to their peers. We refer to this LAC proxy as TightnessCost.  

The intuition behind the second LAC measure (Skills Cost) is anchored in the notion that firms with more highly skilled staff face higher LACs (e.g., Ghaly et al., 2017). For example, the skills required to be an effective cleaner are more prevalent to the general workforce than the skills required to be an effective nuclear physicist so a company looking to fill a nuclear physicist position finds it more challenging (and incurs higher LACs) than a company looking to recruit a new cleaner.  

The third LAC measure is Hiring Cost. Many factors influence the hiring activity of companies. For instance, firms that are growing rapidly will likely look to hire more staff than firms that have stable levels of sales. However, there is evidence (e.g., Varejao & Portugal, 2007) that LACs are one factor that influences the hiring activity of firms. Firms that have difficulties searching for and training new staff are less likely to hire new staff than firms that are identical in all respects but have lower LACs.  

### 2.2. Asymmetric information and labor adjustment costs  

Information asymmetry is an important principle in financial economics with far-reaching implications. Akerlof (1970) describes the impact of a mismatch of information around second-hand car quality between sellers and buyers and the implications of “lemons” on the functioning of markets. Hall and Lazaer (1984) point out that information asymmetry is an important aspect of labor-firm relations. Firms do know ex-ante the productivity of their workers and workers are not aware of all firm-related information, which can create uncertainty regarding their employment. Wesp and Dickersin (2010) suggest that firms use signing bonuses to help mitigate employee concerns and signal that they believe the employee will be a good “fit' for the firm, while Xu and Yang (2016) find that larger signing bonuses are evident in firms with greater information asymmetry. The existence of organized labor also plays a role in the information environment. Kenno and Free (2018) show that unions and management use accounting information to further their interests in negotiations. Hilary (2006) finds that strong organized labor is associated with higher information asymmetry in the form of larger bid-ask spreads, which they suggest is due to management's reluctance to reveal information that weakens their position in collective bargaining. Moreover, Bova (2013) finds unionized firms are more likely to disclose negative information and miss targets. More recently,Aobdia and Cheng (2018) show that non-unionized firms operating in unionized industries engage in the strategic disclosure of good news when their unionized competitors are engaging in labor renegotiations. We contribute to this literature around the impact of asymmetric information on labor in many ways. First, we focus on the impact that asymmetric information exerts on LACs across the entire firm rather than one dimension of LACs, such as signing bonuses for a group of workers. Second, we use accepted shocks to the information environment which allows us to reach conclusions about causality.  

Our paper also sits within a broader literature regarding the impact of asymmetric information on firms and markets. Copeland and Galai (1983) and Glosten and Milgrom (1985) show that asymmetric information impacts the cost of trading, and Kelly and Ljungqvist (2012) suggest this is the main channel through which information asymmetry impacts asset pricing. Asymmetric information also impacts the cost of capital. Easley and O'Hara (2004) find investors require a larger return to hold stocks when there is greater private information, while Lee and Masulis (2009) show that poor accounting quality is associated with higher SEO flotation costs due to higher uncertainty about the firm's financial condition. Billet and Yu (2016) show that open-market share repurchases result in much larger positive abnormal returns in opaque firms than transparent firms.  

## 3. Data, variable measurement, and descriptive statistics  

### 3.1. Measuring labor adjustment costs  

We include all common stocks listed on NYSE, Nasdaq, and Amex from CRSP in our sample and provide all variable definitions in Appendix 1. The LAC proxy we consider is a LAC Index based on Tightness Cost, Skills Cost, and Hiring Cost. Following Kuehn et al. (2017), Labor Market Tightness is calculated by dividing the vacancy index by the product of the unemployment rate and labor force participation rate. The monthly labor force participation and unemployment rates are from the Current Population Survey of the Bureau of Labor Statistics,5 while the vacancy index is from the Conference Board. We then regress each stock's excess return on the market excess return and the change in Labor Market Tightness and measure Labor Market Tightness Sensitivity as the coefficient of the Labor Market Tightness variable. Firms that experience the lowest return when the labor market is tight (i.e., those with negative Labor Market Tightness Sensitivity coefficients) have the largest LACs. However, for consistency across our LAC proxies, we report the negative of Labor Market Tightness Sensitivity (Tightness Cost) which has a positive relation with LACs.6  

The second LAC Index input is the Labor Skills Index, which as Ghaly et al. (2017) note, is an industry-level index (p. 3643) "that measures the weighted-average skill level of the occupations within an industry, ranging from one to five." The index is calculated using OES data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics7 and the U.S. Department of Labor $\mathsf{O}^{*}\mathrm{NET}$ occupation classification based on skill levels.8 The Labor Skills Index is calculated by the industry as follows: First, the number of employees in each of five job “zones” is counted, where zone 1 includes roles that require little skill, and zone 5 covers roles that require an extensive skill. Second, the number of employees in each zone is multiplied by the job zone classification number (1 to 5). Third, this product is divided by the total number of employees in the industry. As Belo, Li, Lin, and Zhao (2017) highlight, various aspects of the employment process, including worker screening and selection, are more difficult in jobs with requirements for specialist skills so there is a positive relation between the Labor Skills Index (Skills Cost) and LACs.  

The third LAC Index factor is based on the Hiring Rate. We obtain the Compustat employee number data (item EMP) and divide the change in employee numbers by the number of employees at the start of the period to arrive at the Hiring Rate. ### 3.3. Natural experiments  

We investigate the existence of a causal link between the information environment and LACs using two exogenous shocks to asymmetric information. As Jiang (2017) notes, exogenous shocks that happen naturally are a superior mechanism to the instrumental variable approach which is widely used in the literature. First, we use the broker closure natural experiment of Kelly and Ljungqvist (2012) and broker mergers as per Hong and Kacperczyk (2010). Kelly and Ljungqvist (2012) suggest that decisions around broker firm closures are independent of the prospects of the firms followed by the brokers and are, therefore, exogenous. Our broker closure sample is as per Chen and Lin (2017).9 This includes 30 brokerage closures impacting 1425 stocks over the 2000-2010 period. The sample is derived from searching the IBES database for a list of brokers who exit and then searching Factiva to confirm the disappearance is due to the closure. This is then complemented with the list of broker closures provided by Kelly and Ljungqvist (2012).  

Broker mergers typically result in a reduction in broker number (e.g., Chen & Lin, 2017), so these events can expectedly lead to a reduction in coverage and an increase in asymmetric information. Our broker merger sample is also from Chen and Lin (2017). This is generated by searching the Thomson Reuters SDC M&A database for transactions where both the acquirer and target primary Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) codes are6211 or6282 and $100\%$ of the target is acquired. The acquirer and target names are then matched with the broker names in IBEs. This results in a sample of 24 merger events. Following Chen and Lin (2017) we group broker merger and closure samples and generate results for 54 broker exits. We also impose the restrictions of requiring the firms covered by the brokers who close. To remain in the IBES sample in year t $^{+1}$ , and for broker mergers, we only include firms that are covered by both the acquirer and target broker before the merger and by the merged entity following the merger.  

Our second asymmetric information shock is the 2o01 move to decimalization. This improves liquidity (e.g., Fang et al., 2009) and improved liquidity makes a company more attractive to large shareholders and those wanting to form blocks (e.g., Edmans, 2009). This typically leads to less information asymmetry (e.g., Boone & White, 2015), as the threat of blockholder exit is an important consideration for management (e.g., Bharath et al., 2013). As Brogaard, Li, and Xia (2017) note, the SEC required all U.S. stock markets to convert all quotes from fractional pricing (the previous minimum increment had been 1/16 of a dollar) to decimal pricing with a minimum price change of $\$0.01$ by April 2001. This event is well suited to our analysis as while liquidity, in general, improved following decimalization (e.g., Bessembinder, 2003), there is a larger cross-sectional variation in the liquidity improvement across stocks (e.g., Brogaard et al., 2017).  

While decimalization is a static single shock that exogenously reduces asymmetric information, the broker closures and mergers are staggered multiple shocks that exogenously increase asymmetric information. Hence, the two shocks together help establish the robustness of the results and boost the confidence in our causal interpretation. Finally, we use a short window before and after each of the three shocks as significant changes in unobserved variables are less likely to simultaneously occur over shorter windows.

The negative relation between information quality and LACs suggests that firms with poorer information environments can expect to find it more difficult to retain and attract workers. This is consistent with the notion that employees are concerned about their future job security and earnings when they are uncertain about the financial health of their employer. The negative information quality - LAC relation points against LACs being lower in firms with weaker information environments and the explanations that could support this. These may include it being a benefit that employees do not know the true condition of the firm if this is generally negative. Alternatively, a more opaque environment may be seen as a positive from the perspective of their being less risk of competitors obtaining firm intellectual property and this having an impact on firm profitability and their ability to maintain staffinglevels.  

### 4.2.Possible factors influencing the information quality -LAC index relation  

In this section, we consider whether financing constraints, financial performance, and firm growth influence the relation between asymmetric information and the LAC Index. As Bushman and Smith (2001) note, transparency around financial accounting information reveals both good and bad opportunities for potential and current employees to invest their human capital. Indeed, such employee behaviors come with no surprise because Brown and Matsa (2016) document that job seekers carefully base their decisions on the potential employers’ financial conditions, and firms with financial difficulties (i.e., distress) experience a reduction in both quantity and quality of job applicants. It is, therefore, possible that information environment improvement leading to the revelation of less financial constraints, stronger firm performance, and greater firm growth makes employees more likely to join and less likely to leave a company, resulting in a greater impact of information quality increases onLACs.  

Papers such as Michaels et al. (2019) find that financial constraints impact wages and employment. Employees are therefore likely to be more attracted to firms with low financing constraints due to them perceiving these companies to offer more stable employment prospects and better opportunities for increased wages. Improved information quality that reveals this information would therefore be expected to lead to a larger reduction in LACs.  

We use three proxies for financial constraints, including the size and age (SA) index of Hadlock and Pierce (2010), the Whited and Wu (2006) (WW) index, and the Kaplan and Zingales (1997) (KZ) index.13 We define firms with SA, WW, and KZ indices above the median (SA High, WW High, and KZ High, respectively) as being financially constrained. SA Low, WW Low, and KZ Low firms with indices below the median are defined as unconstrained. Table 3 results indicate that the negative relation between LAC and information quality is more pronounced in firms with less financial constraints based on both the KZ and Ww indices. For instance, as the KZ index moves from below to above the median the joint impact with the effect of Info_Qual Index on LAC Index increasesby $24\%$ (0.022/0.093).  

Firms generating stronger current financial performance and growth may be more appealing to current and potential employees. We measure financial performance as return on assets (ROA), return on equity (ROE), and return on sales (ROs), and growth as asset growth, sales growth, and research and development (R&D) expenditure. The results in Table 3 Panels B and C indicate the impact of information quality on LACs is stronger when the improved information quality reveals stronger financial performance and growth. Our results indicate that increased information quality is associated with a larger reduction in LACs in firms where transparency reveals less financial constraints, better financial performance, and faster growth. However, improved information quality that reveals firms with more financial constraints, and weaker performance and growth does not increase LACs.

### 4.1. DiD analysis  

In an attempt to establishing the causality between information quality and LACs, we now use the staggered broker closures and mergers and the 2001 decimalization described in section 3.3 as exogenous shocks to information quality. In this section, the results generated by the DiD method has at least two advantages over the standard regression analysis. First, it guards against the possibility of an omitted variable influencing  both  asymmetric  information and $L A C s;$ hence,being responsible for a spurious relation in the regression analysis. Second, the DiD approach allows us to establish whether there is a causal relation between asymmetric information and LACs and rule out the possibility of reverse causality.  

We begin by considering whether the two shocks we utilize have an impact on information quality using the following DiD regression:  

$$
I n f o.Q u a l I n d e x_{i,t}=\alpha+\beta_{l}T r e a t e d^{\ast}P o s t+\beta_{2}T r e a t e d+\beta_{3}P o s t+\gamma C o n t r o l s_{i,t}+\varepsilon_{i,t}
$$  

where Treated is a dummy variable that equals one (zero) if a firm is in the treated (control) group. We apply propensity score matching (PSM) using the controls of Size, ROA,Leverage, Cash, PPE, R&D,and Employees measured in the year immediately before the event year. The predicted probabilities or propensity scores are then used to match firms in the two groups, with each firm in the treated group matched to a firm with the same three-digit SIC code in the control group with a propensity score within 0.01 caliper without replacement. Post is a dummy variable that is equal to one for the post exogenous asymmetric information shock (either the broker mergers and closures or the decimalization) year and zero for the pre-shock year. Treated\*Post is an interaction variable that captures the change in information quality of treated firms relative to that of control firms in the post-shock year compared to the pre-shock year and the controls.  

To ensure an accurate test, we require treated and matched control firms to have similar firm characteristics before the exogenous shocks but a different degree of change in asymmetric information after the shocks. The results in Table 5 Panel A indicate that we can reject the null hypothesis that firm characteristics are statistically significantly different before the exogenous shock. For broker mergers and closures, the treatment group consists of firms experiencing a reduction in broker coverage (i.e., those who lose coverage by at least one analyst due to the brokerage house closures and mergers) and a corresponding increase in asymmetric information. The control group contains firms with no change in broker coverage (i.e., those who do not experience any analyst loss) or asymmetric information. Our definitions of treated and control firms in the broker mergers and closures settings are consistent with those adopted in prior studies (e.g. Billett et al., 2017; Chen & Lin, 2017; Li et al., 2019).

## 5. Conclusions  

Labor adjustment costs (LACs) represent important friction in labor markets and impose a substantial financial burden on companies. The costs associated with hiring, training, firing, and lost productivity can equate to the payroll costs for one year. However, these costs are difficult to measure so proxies need to be used. Our contribution is determining whether a firm's information environment has an impact on an index based on three LAC proxies from the literature. Past papers have noted that information asymmetry is an important feature of labor markets with prospective employees having incomplete information about the firm. However, the impact of the information environment on LACs has not been addressed which may be due to empirical challenges regarding LACs measurement and endogeneity.  

We create a LAC Index based on three components: First, the sensitivity of firm returns to the tightness of the labor market (Tightness Cost). Firms that experience low returns when the labor market is tight have higher LACs. Second, the Skills Cost, or the weighted average skill levels of workers in an industry. Higher skilled workers are more difficult to replace so firms in industries with a higher Skills Cost have higher LACs. Third, given that adjustment costs influence the frequency of adjustment (hiring rate) with less frequent adjustment in firms where LACs are higher, we use a hiring rate variable, Hiring Cost.  

Given there is no consensus on the best measure of information quality, we form an information quality index (Info_Qual Index), which includes the following: A measure of the responsiveness of stock prices to earnings changes, the number of analysts following a firm, the forecast dispersion of analyst estimates, the readability of financial statements, a price delay measure, serial correlation in stock returns, a measure of information asymmetry and the bid-ask spread.  

We find a negative relation between information quality and the LAC Index. This result holds in general but is stronger when the increased information quality relates to firms with low financing constraints, stronger financial performance, and growth, which suggests that these employer qualities are particularly attractive to employees. We also find that LACs are a channel through which information quality impacts firm value. An increase in transparency has a stronger positive impact on firm value when LACs are lower.  

We use two natural experiments to capture changes in the information environment. These are broker closures and mergers, and decimalization. Broker closures and mergers result in a reduction in the number of analysts following a firm which, due to the role analysts play in improving the information environment, reduces information quality. Decimalization improves liquidity and liquidity increases encourage the formation of block holdings which, in turn, leads to greater management disclosure and improvements in information quality. The results from this analysis indicate that the link between information quality and the LAC Index is causal.
